oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Quantification and comparison of low frequency microparticle collection mechanism in an open rectangular chamber
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: AGRAWAL, P
GANDHI, PS
NEILD, A
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: PARTICLES
MANIPULATION
SEPARATION
SURFACE
CELLS
ULTRASOUND
SYSTEMS
FORCES
CHIPS
FLOW
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Low frequency actuations can be used in open fluid systems to manipulate particles at the solid-liquid interface. The generation of capillary waves at resonance at the liquid-air interface results in the collection of particles over multiple cycles. A simulated flow field for a rectangular chamber undergoing vertical vibrations is used, along with a particle tracing algorithm, to track the movement of particles at different regions in the chamber; these data have been supported by experimental findings. Particle motion over a cycle has been characterized for this system and compared with the collection observed in horizontally actuated chambers. The relationship between collection behavior and a range of different particle and fluid field parameters is presented qualitatively and quantitatively. (C) 2014 AIP Publishing LLC.
